title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Controlled Study To Evaluate The Efficacy and Safety of Short-Term Plasma Exchange Followed by Long-Term Plasmapheresis With Infusion of Human Albumin Combined With Intravenous Immunoglobulin In Patients With Mild-Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the changes in the cognitive, functional, behavioral and global domains based on the different applicable psychometric batteries and scales.
description_detailed: A clinical trial comprised of 350 subjects with probable mild to moderate Alzheimer's Disease (AD) will be conducted primarily to determine whether plasmapheresis with infusion of human albumin combined with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is able to modify patient's cognitive, functional, behavioral and global domains. There will be 3 treatment groups and 1 control group. The subjects will be randomized in a 1:1:1:1 proportion.

groups.title: High Albumin + Immunoglobulin
groups.description: Therapeutic plasma exchange with albumin 5% (intensive treatment period) + Low volume plasma exchange with high dose of albumin 20% or immunoglobulin 5% (maintenance treatment period)

groups.title: Low Albumin + Immunoglobulin
groups.description: Therapeutic plasma exchange with albumin 5% (intensive treatment period) + Low volume plasma exchange with low dose of albumin 20% or immunoglobulin 5% (maintenance treatment period)

groups.title: Low Albumin
groups.description: Therapeutic plasma exchange with albumin 5% (intensive treatment period) + Low volume plasma exchange with low dose of albumin 20% (maintenance treatment period)

groups.title: Control (Sham) Group
groups.description: Simulated plasma exchange procedure

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: 322 evaluable subjects from analysis population were defined as the overall study population (N = 347) without 25 randomized no treated subjects

measures.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measures.populationDescription: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

measures.title: Baseline Mini-Mental State Examination total score
measures.description: Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is a widely used brief 30-point questionnaire test of cognitive function among the elderly; it includes tests of orientation, registration, attention and calculation, memory (recall, naming and repetition), language (comprehension, reading and writing) and visual-spatial skills. The score ranges from 0 to 30 and is obtained by summing the points corresponding to each answer. Lower score indicates more impaired cognition.

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog) Total Score (Changes From Baseline to 14 Months)
outcomeMeasures.description:
ADAS-Cog total score as a change from baseline to 14 months

The ADAS-Cog Scale is a questionnaire that assesses cognitive performance in 12 different domains. The domains are: word recall, commands, constructional praxis, delayed word-recall task, naming objects/figures, ideational praxis, orientation, word recognition, remembering test instructions, comprehension, word finding difficulty, and spoken language ability. The total score ranges from 0-80 where a higher score indicates more cognitive impairment.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Evaluable population with ADAS-Cog measurement at 14 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study-Activities of Daily Living (ADCS-ADL) Total Score (Changes From Baseline to 14 Months)
outcomeMeasures.description:
ADCS-ADL total score as a change from baseline to 14 months

The ADCS-ADL comprises 23 questions covering a wide array of activities of daily living. Many of the activities begin with an assessment of whether that activity is relevant and then, if yes, follow with an assessment of the difficulty. The total score over all activities ranges from 0-78 where a higher score indicates more autonomy (better outcome).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Evaluable population with ADCS-ADL measurement at 14 months

adverseEventsModule.description:
1 randomized subject in the control group was implanted by error with a real central catheter and was then transfered and treated as high albumin + immunoglobulin subject.

Therefore, this subject was considered for evaluable population as control (control group \[n=80\] and high albumin + immunoglobulin group \[n=78\]), but moved to high albumin + immunoglobulin group for safety analysis (control group \[n=79\] and high albumin + immunoglobulin group \[n=79\]).

seriousEvents.term: Intentional medical device removal by patient

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certainAgreement.otherDetails: A 18-month post-study period is reserved for a joint, multi-center publication of study results. After this period, individual sites may publish results provided that the Sponsor is allowed 60 days to review any proposed publication for removal of confidential, protected, and trademarked material prior to submission with an option to delay publication up to 120 days if needed to protect its interests. The Sponsor shall retain the option to receive acknowledgment for its sponsorship of the study.

drug: Plasma exchange / plasmapheresis (therapeutic plasma exchange, TPE and low-volume PE)
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is therapeutic plasma exchange followed by long‑term plasmapheresis with infusion of human albumin and IVIG — a biologic/procedural approach intended to mobilize and remove circulating amyloid‑β and related pathogenic factors and thereby modify AD pathology (i.e., disease‑targeting mechanism rather than a symptomatic cognitive enhancer). citeturn0search1turn0search7

Act (key details extracted): This is the AMBAR program: multicenter, randomized, controlled trial using an initial 6‑week period of weekly conventional plasma exchange (TPE) followed by ~12 months of monthly low‑volume PE, with albumin replacement (different doses) with or without IVIG; randomized vs. a sham (placebo) PE control. Primary/Co‑primary outcomes included ADAS‑Cog and ADCS‑ADL with secondary cognitive, functional, behavioral and biomarker endpoints. citeturn0search7turn0search6

Act (supporting evidence / mechanism): Earlier and phase‑II data showed PE with albumin replacement altered plasma and CSF Aβ levels and associated cognitive improvements, supporting a disease‑modifying rationale (mobilization/reduction of Aβ between compartments). citeturn0search1turn0search8

Reflect (classification decision): Because the intervention is a biologic/procedural therapy (apheresis with biologic replacements) that explicitly targets Alzheimer’s pathology (amyloid mobilization/removal) rather than being a small molecule enzyme/modulator or a symptomatic cognitive enhancer or psychiatric symptom treatment, the correct category is "disease-targeted biologic." This trial is not a diagnostic or non‑therapeutic study; it is therapeutic and pathology‑directed. citeturn0search0turn0search6

Notes / ambiguity: This is not a monoclonal antibody or vaccine (common exemplars of 'biologic') but a blood‑exchange biologic/procedural approach; some terminology could place it between a device/procedure and biologic replacement therapy, but its mechanism and endpoints align it with disease‑targeted biologic interventions. The trial used a sham PE control. citeturn0search6turn0search2
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is therapeutic plasma exchange / plasmapheresis with human albumin replacement ± IVIG explicitly intended to mobilize/remove circulating amyloid-β (Aβ) and related pathogenic factors to alter AD pathology rather than only treat symptoms. This disease‑targeting mechanism maps directly to the CADRO category for amyloid-beta. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Act: Key extracted details — multicenter AMBAR trial used an initial 6‑week period of weekly therapeutic plasma exchange followed by ~12 months of monthly low‑volume plasmapheresis with albumin replacement (Albutein® 5%/20%) with or without intravenous immunoglobulin (Flebogamma®). The protocol and publications state changes in plasma and CSF Aβ were measured and the program was designed on the hypothesis that Aβ bound to circulating albumin can be mobilized/removed by plasma exchange. These factual points come from the AMBAR study design and primary results publications. citeturn0search1turn0search4turn0search6

Reflect: Classification decision — AMBAR is a pathology‑directed, biologic/procedural therapy whose stated mechanism is mobilization/removal of amyloid‑β. Under CADRO this is most specifically A) Amyloid beta rather than inflammation, tau, or a symptomatic neurotransmitter target. Although the intervention is procedural (apheresis) with biologic replacements (albumin, IVIG), the therapeutic target is Aβ biology; therefore the correct CADRO category is 'A) Amyloid beta'. Confirmatory sources: the peer‑reviewed AMBAR primary results and trial design, and Grifols’ description of the trial rationale. citeturn0search0turn0search4turn0search2

Web search results used (titles / short notes):
- "A randomized, controlled clinical trial of plasma exchange with albumin replacement for Alzheimer's disease: Primary results of the AMBAR Study" — Alzheimer's & Dementia (primary results paper; describes design, endpoints, mechanism hypothesis, and outcomes). citeturn0search0turn0search6
- PubMed record: "Plasma exchange for Alzheimer's disease Management by Albumin Replacement (AMBAR) trial: Study design and progress" — describes trial design and biomarker rationale. citeturn0search1
- Grifols press release and company summary of AMBAR results — describes hypothesis that plasma albumin binds Aβ and the rationale for plasma exchange and albumin replacement. citeturn0search2turn0search5
